data.title: Use 32-bit version of 7zip if needed
data.body:
The "ExtractFilesV1" task uses a 64-bit version of the 7z.exe binary which doesn't work on 32-bit systems and, more importantly, on Windows on ARM.
Let's use a 32-bit version of 7zip if the task is running under 32-bit version of Node.js.

_Somebody will have to create and upload an archive with 32-bit version of 7zip to the storage._
https://www.7-zip.org/download.html

data.title: Updating VsTestV2 Task Version
TFS release - “Fetch Build Artifact” fails because of OS version
data.body:
### Environment 
* My agent version for the build machine is 2.141.1.
* My agent version for the deployment group machine is 2.160.1

### Issue Description
I have a TFS UI build definition for a c# unit test project. Before the build finishes, the artifacts are published using the “Publish Build Artifacts” task (published to Azure Pipelines). It’s built on an agent that runs on Windows10 x64 (but built using the “Visual Studio Build” task using both x86 and x64 platforms).

I also have a TFS UI release environment, which runs on a deployment group, which in turn needs to fetch the build artifacts of said build using the “Fetch Build Artifact” task.

When the release runs on an agent that runs on a x64 Windows10 or x64-Windows7 machine, all goes well.

But, when the release runs on an agent that runs on a x86 Windows 7 machine, the task “Fetch Build Artifact” fails with the error: The specified executable is not a valid application for this OS platform

Any help would be greatly appreciated - I’ve tried everything I can think of, but I’m relatively new to TFS.

### Notes:
* I’ve tried building on an x86 win7 machine - “fetch build artifact” in the release still doesn’t work.
* I’ve tried the “download build artifact” instead, still doesn’t work.
* the ”download pipeline artifact” task itself doesn’t work (shows as “preview”).

data.title: Allow multiple sql files with pattern matching for SQL Server Database Deploy
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: SqlDacpacDeploymentOnMachineGroup

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Private

## Issue Description
When using pattern matching to find the SQL file to deploy, an error is raised when there is more than 1 one: `Found more than one file to deploy with search pattern **/*.sql. There can be only one.`. But it is possible to execute multiple SQL files _without_ pattern matching, by separating them with a ; as in `file1.sql;file2.sql`.

Please add to ability to have multiple sql files deployed when using pattern matching.

See also https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/10195#issuecomment-493855770

### Task logs
N/A

N/A

data.title: Add support for deterministic builds to PublishSymbols
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: PublishSymbols

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

When using [Deterministic builds](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/csharp/language-reference/compiler-options/deterministic-compiler-option) in a VSTS build pipeline the compiler generates the same binary and .pdb file even if the working directory is different from run to run. This happens by replacing the variable part of a path with a fixed string using the [PathMap option](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/csharp/language-reference/compiler-options/pathmap-compiler-option).

Unfortunately this does not work well with PublishSymbols that requires that source files exist at the locations specified in the PDB file.

I propose to add a PathMap parameters to the PublishSymbols task to achieve the same outcome.

In my case it would map ```C:\Framework\AccountPool\AccountPool.cs``` back to ```D:\a\_work\42\s\Framework\AccountPool\AccountPool.cs```
### Task logs
When running the pipeline with
```
    <Deterministic>true</Deterministic>
    <PathMap>D:\a\_work\42\s\=C:\</PathMap>
```
the PublishSymbols task fails to find the source files
```
##[debug]Entering Get-SourceFilePaths.
##[debug] SymbolsFilePath: 'D:\a\_work\42\s\target\Release\x64\ACME\net462\ACME.pdb'
##[warning]Unable to index one or more source files for symbols file 'D:\a\_work\42\s\target\Release\x64\ACME.package\net462\ACME.pdb'.
2020-01-06T16:52:41.1490076Z ##[debug]Processed: ##vso[task.logissue type=warning]Unable to index one or more source files for symbols file 'D:\a\_work\42\s\target\Release\x64\ACME.package\net462\ACME.pdb'.
2020-01-06T16:52:41.1490669Z ##[debug]One or more source files not under sources root directory: D:\a\_work\42\s\
2020-01-06T16:52:41.1607592Z ##[debug]Paths: C:\
2020-01-06T16:52:41.1644739Z ##[debug] Framework\AccountPool\AccountPool.cs
```

data.title: Consider adding authorization on SQL server using Service Connection
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: SqlAzureDacpacDeployment

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

In my organization we're using Dacpac to create not only database structure but also map SQL users with AAD groups. As such operations can be [performed only with AAD accounts](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/sql-database/sql-database-aad-authentication-configure?tabs=azure-powershell#create-contained-database-users-in-your-database-mapped-to-azure-ad-identities), we're looking for an option to make our CD pipeline task to authorize on Azure SQL server using an AD account. For a number of reasons putting account password to variables or setting up an own agent and using 'Active Directory - Integrated' auth method are not viable for us.

My suggestion would be to leverage /AccessToken feature of SQLPackage and extent SqlAzureDacpacDeployment task with ability to authenticate on target SQL server as service principal used in Azure Devops service connection.

This should be relatively simple using methods ADAL as shown in [this example](https://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/stefan_stranger/2018/06/06/connect-to-azure-sql-database-by-obtaining-a-token-from-azure-active-directory-aad/)
The same, of course, can be done in a custom Powershell script ran in AzurePowershell task, but in such case it would be required to pass service principal password to the script as a variable, which is a considerable security weakening compared to obtaining the password inside the task using Get-VstsEndpoint

    inputs:
      mavenPomFile: 'pom.xml'
      mavenOptions: '-Xmx3072m'
      javaHomeOption: 'JDKVersion'
      jdkVersionOption: '1.8'
      jdkArchitectureOption: 'x64'
      publishJUnitResults: true
      testResultsFiles: '**/TEST-*.xml'
      goals: 'package'
      options: '--settings settings.xml'
      **codeCoverageToolOption: JaCoCo
      codeCoverageSourceDirectories: epubcheck-service/src/main,epubcheck-service/src/test
      codeCoverageClassFilesDirectories: epubcheck-service/target/classes,epubcheck-service/target/test-classes**
      sonarQubeRunAnalysis: true

If I comment the codeCoverage parameters then the Maven build task completes successfully. Only when I add the codeCoverage parameters on a multi-module project, I am getting the above-mentioned error. 

Can somebody who used Azure DevOps pipeline for building Java maven build and Jacoco code coverage tool help me?

data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*:  Question

**Enter Task Name**: Azure Key Vault  


## Environment
- Server - **Azure Pipelines** or TFS on-premises?
    
    **- If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number:** 

> 1.  Have pushed the same credentials to a cloud system during a build pipeline to test; no errors.
>  2.  Current issue is using a release pipeline and pushing credentials by same method to private agent; error received.


- Agent - Hosted or Private: 

    **- If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version:** 

> Microsoft Windows Server 2019 Datacenter
> agent v2.160.1 (commit 8c04bd1)


## Issue Description

The company utilises SSL inspection on its networks. We run the self-hosted agent with a certificate using the generated Powershell from Azure DevOps plus the additional parameter **"--sslcacert cacert.pem"** following the advice from (1), specifically the section titled **"Work with SSL client certificate"**.


A release pipeline is used to make a number of Secrets from an Azure Key Vault available through a linked variable group, scope set to entire release.


While running the release pipeline the Azure Key Vault task fails due to an error:
`Self signed certificate in certificate chain`
The Key Vault task cannot be configured to continue on error.

**Note:** Instances of the task DownloadBuildArtficats honour the sslcacert setting and function as expected.


This behaviour has been mentioned before on **MicrosoftDocs** (2), and also in **azure-pipelines-agent** (3).


**Question:** Is it fair to assume that the Key Vault task requires all the benefits offered by enciphered data transfer, and is why self-signed certificates are not recognised as this could potentially compromise the data?


(1) https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/agents/certificate?view=azure-devops-2019

(2) https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/vsts-docs/issues/5501

(3) https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-agent/issues/1820

Currently unable to provide, too much data to sanitise.

data.title: DotNetCoreCLI restore command does not support Azure artifacts views
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreCLIV2

## Issue Description

vstsFeed format is projectID/feedID
If you want to select a view in Azure Artifacts you'd need projectID/feedID@viewID

but this results in invalid XML in Nuget.config, eventually resulting in dotnet restore returning
``The '@' character, hexadecimal value 0x40, cannot be included in a name``

reason is that the task puts anything after the "/" into Feed.Name, because it expects only a GUID.

As far as I can see there is no possibility (currently) to use feedsToUse: 'select' and select a view in Azure Artifacts. You can only select the complete feed.

data.title: DownloadPipelineArtifact permissions lost on ubuntu
data.body:
*Type*: Bug
**Enter Task Name**: DownloadPipelineArtifact

## Issue Description

When using PublishPipelineArtifact with DownloadPipelineArtifact on ubuntu-latest (assuming other distros as well), the artifacts published then downloaded will not maintain execution rights.

An example of this would be using the `-outfile` option in Terraform, which will bundle downloaded plugins into the generated artifact.  If the plugin files do not have execution permissions set once extracted to the target deployment agent, the subsequent Terraform steps will fail due to permission issues.

As a quick workaround I run a bash script after the DownloadPipelineArtifact step to chmod +x the plug-ins, but it would be preferable to maintain the file permissions using the task itself.

data.title: Added agent automated analysis task
XamarinAndroidV1 does not yet surface the new Android App Bundle publishing format option
data.body:
## Required Information

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: Xamarin.Android  

https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/XamarinAndroidV1/

## Environment

- Server - Azure Pipelines.

## Issue Description

### Current behavior

The [Xamarin.Android task](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/build/xamarin-android) has a dedicated boolean input for `createAppPackage`, described as *Passes the target (/t:PackageForAndroid) during build to generate an APK*:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4934473/70964323-42dd0c00-2040-11ea-92d1-2e5cb384d8e1.png)

### New feature to add

As of the recent Xamarin.Android SDK 10.0 and 10.1 releases, the Xamarin.Android SDK supports a new `AndroidPackageFormat` MSBuild property that allows creating packages that follow the [Android App Bundle publishing format](https://developer.android.com/platform/technology/app-bundle).

Currently, users can select this packaging format by adding an argument like `-p:AndroidPackageFormat=aab` to the `msbuildArguments` input. But since `createAppPackage` is its own input separate from the `target` input, it would be nice to surface the Android App Bundle packaging format similarly.

One option could be to make the `createAppPackage` a multiple choice option instead of a boolean option so that users would have a list of choices similar to:

  * Do not create app package.
  * Create APK.
  * Create Android App Bundle.

To me, it seems that the DotNetCoreCli@2 does not reuse the same credentials from NugetAuthenticate (but I may be wrong, this happen very often ;))

It seems related to https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/issues/10377 but I am not sure either

data.title: [Maven] Use predefined JAVA_HOME variable
data.body:
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: Maven

## Issue Description

I'm running my Maven build inside a container with only one JDK and Maven installed. I already have a JAVA_HOME correctly set, so I don't need Maven Task to set it for me.

There is no optimal solution for me now: 1) I can change my Docker image to set a "JAVA_HOME_<VERSION>_<ARCH>" variable that would be used only on Azure Devops; or 2) use "javaHomeOption: 'Path'" which is not as generic as a JAVA_HOME environment variable.

I propose the creation of a new "javaHomeOption" value that uses the predefined JAVA_HOME variable. Perhaps this should be the default option, as "JAVA_HOME" is default on a Java build environment.

data.title: Java Tool Installer task select pre-installed Java version
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: Java Tool Installer task  

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
- Agent - Hosted

## Issue Description

Microsoft hosted agents typically come pre-installed with multiple versions of Java, one of which activated by default. For example, currently pools ubuntu-latest and windows-latest include Javas 7, 8, and 11, and 8 is active.

Java Tool Installer task  could gracefully handle selecting among pre-installed Javas. Suggested implementation: a new **jdkSourceOption** _'Pre-installed'_, which attempts to match on the **versionSpec** and **jdkArchitectureOption** parameters, and if found adjusts **JAVA_HOME** and **PATH** environment variables appropriately, avoiding overhead of download & install.

## Required Information
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug /Question

**Enter Task Name**: Visual Studio Test

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
    
- Agent - Hosted 

## Issue Description

We have about 500 coded UI tests running on 6 agents in parallel. The batch size is configured to take into account the running time, but it does not work. The batches always contain the same number of tests and there is usually one agent that takes considerably longer to execute.

### Task logs
```
2019-12-05T00:56:07.3046041Z [RunStatistics]This execution slice with id '5402', received '88' testcases to execute out of which '87' is discovered.
```

Windows Server 2008 R2 Standard, 2.140.0
## Issue Description

I'm dealing with inconsistently named instances over my DTAP. What I want my release to do, is to deploy website Flids_O with binding to port 1234 on application pool Flids_O_Incasso, regardless of existing setup.
It correctly created and updates website "Flids_O", it correctly adds a binding to port 1234 under website "Flids_O", it correctly creates or updates application pool "Flids_O_Incasso".
What it fails to do, is assign website "Flids_O" to application pool "Flids_O_Incasso", if it's current application pool is not "Flids_O_Incasso".

A work around I've found is to add 'set site /site.name:"Flids_O" -[path='/'].applicationPool:"Flids_O_Incasso"' to the "Additional appcmd.exe commands" tab.

list here (V# not needed):  
https://github.com/Microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises?
    
    - If using TFS on-premises, provide the version: 
    
    - If using Azure Pipelines, provide the account name, team project name, build definition name/build number: 


- Agent - Hosted or Private: 
    
    - If using Hosted agent, provide agent queue name:

    - If using private agent, provide the OS of the machine running the agent and the agent version: 

## Issue Description

Our admin accounts are locked down, making it a bit difficult to find the proper AD account that has the necessary login permissions. data.title: Xcode task does not support determining iCloud entitlement with app extensions
data.body:
## Required Information
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: Xcode V4/V5

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines or TFS on-premises? - n/a, both
- Agent - Hosted or Private: n/a, both

## Issue Description
When building an iOS application and exporting the IPA from it when the application has multiple targets (i.e. a host application and multiple extensions) which have dedicated embedded provisioning profiles - if only the embedded profile of the host application has iCloud entitlements, it won't register this.

i.e. consider the built xcarchive contains multiple targets with embedded provisioning profiles in the following locations under `output/build/archive/My App.xcarchive/Products/Applications`
- My App Keyboard Extension.appex/embedded.mobileprovision
- My App Share Extension.appex/embedded.mobileprovision
- My App Thumbnail Extension.appex/embedded.mobileprovision
- My App.app/embedded.mobileprovision

### Task logs

Snippets from debug logs:
```
... ##[debug]4 iOS embedded.mobileprovision file(s) found.
... enumerating over profiles mentioned above ...
... only last one has iCloud entitlements, i.e.
...<key>com.apple.developer.icloud-container-environment</key>
...<array>
...  <string>Production</string>
... <string>Development</string>
...</array>
...
```

The last profile will not be considered to look for the iCloud entitlements because of how this currently works (checked Xcode 4.130.x - 5.xxx.x):
https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/XcodeV5/xcode.ts#L401
i.e. it takes the iCloud entitlement from the first profile which doesn't have any.

This becomes a problem when not all the extensions of the app have iCloud enabled which they typically don't need to have, as the build will then ultimately fail with

```
... error: exportArchive: exportOptionsPlist error for key 'iCloudContainerEnvironment': expected one of {Development, Production}, but no value was provided
```

as no value gets written to the temporary exportOptions.plist file.

More detailed logs can be shared upon request.

data.title: UseDotNet task useGlobalJson finding algorithm totally unusable
data.body:
Current version.

As per the documentation (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/tool/dotnet-core-tool-installer?view=azure-devops) that is defined as:

* useGlobalJson: true to enable the function
* workingDirectory to specify the path erhe the global.json files should be searched.

SOMEONE seems to have implemented that as searching from the working directory down and then taking a random path. The reality is that as per the global.json file specifications one should start at a specific place (the folder for the solution) and search FROM THERE UP taking the first hit.

My current use case is this:

* We have a repository with multiple solution folders (Source, Source.Backend, Source.Websites etc.)
* There is a global.json in the root folder where the source folders are defined.
* There is in one or two source folders a global.json file that overrides the sdk version for this specific folder.

No problem in Visual Studio. Unusable in Azure.

I have defined a version to find the global.json as this:

- task: UseDotNet@2
  displayName: 'Use .NET Core sdk'
  inputs:
    useGlobalJson: true
    workingDirectory:  '$(Build.SourcesDirectory)/Source.Backend'

The result is:

##[error]Failed to find global.json at and inside path: d:\a\1\s\Source.Backend

Funny thing is: There IS a global.json in the parent directory of that. And global.json is supposed to be searched from the executed solution (which lives in Source.Backend) UPWARD - not downward.

Documentation:

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/global-json

".NET Core SDK looks for a global.json file in the current working directory (which isn't necessarily the same as the project directory) or one of its parent directories."

Whoever implemented this search did not bother reading the documentation and thus it is unusable in the way it is supposed to be used. Which is:

* Compile a solution in a work directlry,
* So use this feature to set the SDK
* Which is either defined globally further up or overridden for specific folders.

For now - sorry - I ahve to roll back this critical feature and stick with an actually working powershell script that was written after reading the specifications of how global.json is supposed to be searched.

data.title: Add the ability to set different variable for each JSON file in variable substitution
data.body:
In variable substitution when I have multiple settings.job for 2 web jobs every file has its own schedule, for example this is JSON file schedule: ``` { "schedule": "0 */5 * * * *" } ``` This modification is aimed to set different schedule for each web job file by adding alias for each sub-file. File format: `{file name}[;{alias}]`. The files would be like this: ``` **/Console-WebJob/settings.job;console **/Emails-WebJob/settings.job;emails ``` And the variables format will be `[{alias};]{variable name}` as in the following:
Variable name Value
console;schedule 0 * */6 * * *
emails;schedule 0 * */7 * * *

data.title: Library files missing for "UsePythonVersion@0" on Windows and Mac
data.body:
This issue was moved from [here](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/vsts-docs/issues/6330).

If I use the task "UsePythonVersion@0" and try to build some C++ binaries that link to python on the mac, it looks like the `.dylib` file can't be found for the enabled version of python. I am using the image `macos-10.14`.

For example, one of my mac builds is [here](https://dev.azure.com/patrickavery0563/mytomviz/_build/results?buildId=224&view=logs). You can see [here](https://dev.azure.com/patrickavery0563/mytomviz/_build/results?buildId=224&view=logs&jobId=e0fca624-2401-5624-f540-1c188feac080&taskId=bbed0958-84ad-58b9-7374-2c95321bdab1&lineStart=1&lineEnd=12&colStart=1&colEnd=42) that python 3.6 was enabled. But when cmake searches for the `.dylib` file, it can't find it, but instead finds the system one [here](https://dev.azure.com/patrickavery0563/mytomviz/_build/results?buildId=224&view=logs&jobId=e0fca624-2401-5624-f540-1c188feac080&taskId=90593842-716e-5c1d-6fac-3c5c8d07c009&lineStart=355&lineEnd=356&colStart=1&colEnd=1) (`/usr/local/opt/python/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.7/lib/libpython3.7m.dylib`). This causes issues later on, since the python executable and shared library are not the same version.

It doesn't appear to me that a `.dylib` file for python is in the hosted tool cache directory (`/Users/runner/hostedtoolcache/Python/3.6.9/x64`).

This doesn't seem to be an issue for Linux. Shared libraries are found and linked to for the different versions of python on `ubuntu-18.04`

\---------------------------------

UPDATE: I also just noticed that the library for the specified version of python on Windows is not being found either. For [this build](https://dev.azure.com/OpenChemistry/tomviz/_build/results?buildId=18), for instance, the Windows version of python is specified to be 3.7, but cmake doesn't find a python 3.7 library, but only this one: `C:/hostedtoolcache/windows/Python/3.8.0/x64/libs/python38.lib`

We can't use python 3.8 here, because we haven't updated some dependencies that fail to build on python 3.8. I printed out the path to be sure, the python 3.7 paths are indeed prepended on Windows, but cmake not finding a python 3.7 library makes me think that it doesn't exist. Are the libraries for previous versions of python present?

This is confirmed to not be an issue on Linux, because python 3.7 was specified, and even though python 3.8 is on the system, the python 3.7 shared libraries were found.

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Bug

**Enter Task Name**: UsePythonVersion

data.title: Gradle@2: Impossible to specify task options
data.body:
## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: Gradle@2

## Environment
Irrelevant

## Issue Description

Currently - as far as I understood - it is not possible to specify options for gradle tasks. You can only specify **global** gradle options. So `gradle --debug clean build` is possible, however `gradle clean test --tests my.package.SomethingTest` is not, because gradle expects `--tests` to be specified **after** the `test` task, but `options` is always putting them **before** the tasks.

data.title: Fix parsing commonName containing slashes
data.body:
I've encountered errors when trying to build an iOS app in AppCenter, when using a certificate containing a slash in commonName (example: `subject=/UID=XXXXXXXXXX/CN=iPhone Distribution: Some Danish Company A/S (YYYYYYYYYY)/OU=YYYYYYYYYY/O=Some Danish Company A/S/C=US`.

This happens because of incorrect parsing of openssl command output (`value.match(/\/CN=([^/]+)/);`) that does not expect slashes in the name.
This commit adds `-nameopt multiline` option to openssl, so that it splits subject into multiple lines, making it possible to distinguish slashes that are part of the name from path separators.

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines
    
- Agent - Private    

## Issue Description

When running the cache task on a private agent the cache is always fully downloaded, even if running on an agent that already downloaded the cache on a previous build.

This might be fast for hosted agents (which I guess run very close to the cache blobs), but for an agent running on premises it takes very long.

Evidence: my current cache for a Nuget restore is at about 1GB, and it is taking about 2 minutes and a half to restore the cache. A `dotnet restore` would take about the same, if done from scratch (sometimes less than the cache restore).

If the download was kept on the agent and not made again, that would not happen.

data.title: Azure yaml if then else for conditions
data.body:
Hi,

At the moment, I have two conditions in my yaml. I want to add more conditions e.g.
('Saturday' and 'ScheduledBuild') and so on. I am unable to find a clean way of having additional conditions without repeating myself with the previous conditions.


```
    - task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
      inputs:
        command: test
        projects: '**/*MyTests/*.csproj'
        arguments: '--verbosity minimal --configuration $(buildConfiguration) --no-build --logger:trx --filter TestCategory!=LongRunningTests --settings $(DefaultUTSettings) /p:AltCover=true /p:AltCoverForce=true /p:AltCoverAssemblyFilter=NUnit /p:AltCoverCobertura="$(CodeCoverageResultsDir)/altcover.cobertura.xml"'
        publishTestResults: true
      continueOnError: true
      displayName: 'dotnet test'
      condition: not(and(succeeded(), eq(variables['DayOfWeek'], 'Sunday'), eq(variables['IsScheduledBuild'], 'True')))
    - task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
      inputs:
        command: test
        projects: '**/*MyTests/*.csproj'
        arguments: '--verbosity minimal --configuration $(buildConfiguration) --no-build --logger:trx --settings $(FullViewsComparisonTestUTSettings) /p:AltCover=true /p:AltCoverForce=true /p:AltCoverAssemblyFilter=NUnit /p:AltCoverCobertura="$(CodeCoverageResultsDir)/altcover.cobertura.xml"'
      continueOnError: true
      displayName: 'dotnet test'
      condition: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['DayOfWeek'], 'Sunday'), eq(variables['IsScheduledBuild'], 'True'))
```

As an example, suppose I want to add a condition for 'ScheduledBuild' other than Sunday, do something else with dotnet test. How do I do it without repeating myself in a complicated way?

```
condition: and(succeeded(), eq(variables['DayOfWeek'], 'Sunday'), 
condition: and(succeeded(), ne(variables['DayOfWeek'], 'Sunday'), 

condition:? <this is the tricky part which I can't understand>. An else condition here would be very helpful.
```

Thanks,
Anubhav.

data.title: provide a way to lock edge module images after successful push to Azure Container Registry
data.body: We use gitversion to generate build number during build of iot edge modules and this same build number is assigned to the image tag. Sometimes, an incorrect configuration for gitversion.yml causes the same build number to be generated for a different commit. By default, **Azure Container Registry** allows the same image tag to be re-used by a new image hash, essentially the same image is updated. To prevent this situation from happening, it would be good to provide a Lock image after push checkbox in the **Azure Iot Edge** task when action is **push module images** . This will prevent future builds that generate duplicate tags from being able to overwrite existing images. I thought locking a repo would do the trick but as it turns out, it also prevents me from being able to push a new image with new tag onto that repo. There does not seem to be an option specified at the repo level to be able to prevent existing tags from being updated. It is very tedious to lock images after the fact since it can only be done one tag at a time per repo.

## Required Information

Entering this information will route you directly to the right team and expedite traction.

*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: DotNetCoreCLI - pack command should allow arguments to passed like the other commands do.

## Environment
Azure Pipelines - Hosted Agent - windows-latest

## Issue Description

Currently there is no way to addition arguments to the pack command e.g `--no-build --no-restore`
This is further limiting as one cannot pass MSBuild properties e.g `/p:Property`

Attempting the following:

```    
- task: DotNetCoreCLI@2
      inputs:
        command: 'pack'
        packagesToPack: 'src/My.Sample.Api/*.csproj'
        packDirectory: '$(Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory)/application'
        versioningScheme: 'off'
        arguments: '/p:NuspecFile=My.Sample.Api.nuspec /p:IsPackable=true --no-build --no-restore'
```

Does not yield the expected results. The following command is run:

`"C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe" pack d:\a\1\s\src\My.Sample.Api\My.Sample.Api.csproj --output d:\a\1\a\application /p:Configuration=Release --verbosity Detailed`

The arguments are ignored. This is inconsistent with the other commands in the DotNetCoreCLI task like build/restore/etc as mentioned in #9789 

The expected result would be

`"C:\Program Files\dotnet\dotnet.exe" pack d:\a\1\s\src\My.Sample.Api\My.Sample.Api.csproj --output d:\a\1\a\application /p:Configuration=Release /p:NuspecFile=My.Sample.Api.nuspec /p:IsPackable=true --no-build --no-restore --verbosity Detailed`

## Note  
There are Azure Pipeline Tasks, specifically AzureResourceGroupDeployment, that instruct people, through its info tooltip, to copy and paste a ARM template GitHub link into their Pipeline task.  The example it provides is a `raw.githubusercontent.com` link that links to its master branch of arm template starter repo. The better approach is to instruct people to use a permalink of the file which includes the commit hash.

data.title: Add option to fail Publish Test Results task when test result file is not found
data.body:
**Question, Bug, or Feature?**  
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: PublishTestResults@2  

## Environment
- Server - Azure Pipelines

## Issue Description

I imagine it is a common pattern to have a test task (with continueOnError: true) followed by a publish task. I've run into the issue a couple times where we will have our test task fail due to setup issues (e.g. not test failures), but the junit output file will not be published. The PublishTestResults task will warn it cannot find the file, but it will not fail the task. I find myself relying heavily on `failTaskOnFailedTests: true`, and wish that I could make this task fail if no output files are found.

### Task logs

For our build setup see [here](https://dev.azure.com/reason-native/reason-native/_build/results?buildId=665). This particular log actually brings up another issue, where failing when the output cannot be parsed would also be nice. I don't think we have a log with the issue I described at the moment, but both things have occurred.

data.title: Allow dotnet test with publish --results-directory to be customized
data.body:
*Type*: Feature

**Enter Task Name**: .NET Core - test

## Environment
Server - Azure Pipelines

## Issue Description

Checking the **Publish test results and code coverage** option sets --results-directory to the agent's temporary directory, making it difficult to isolate a single build's test output when publishing the results of multiple data collectors.

Recommendation: Allow --results-directory to be overridden (via textbox) when **Publish test results and code coverage** is checked.

This would allow users to harvest the output for publishing to additional code coverage tools or overcome shortcomings in the existing tooling (such as the code coverage tab only providing a link instead of an html report).

data.title: Fix "No credentials are available in the security package"
data.body:
Add `<add key="ValidAuthenticationTypes" value="basic"/>` to the package source credentials to prevent nuget/dotnet from trying to authenticate via NTLM/Windows authentication.

This fixes #11768 and the second problem that is described in #10399 next to the feed name encoding problem.

data.title: [Feature Request] XCode5 Legacy Build System
data.body:
**FEATURE REQUEST**

Starting from XCode 10, the legacy build system is deprecated and the New build system is the default.

So I want a new checkbox or property called:
UseModernBuildSystem: false

and it should behave like adding a new argument to xcode command
```-UseModernBuildSystem=0```
or
```-UseModernBuildSystem=NO```


**Actual yaml**
```
- task: Xcode@5
  inputs:
    actions: 'build'
    configuration: 'Release'
    sdk: 'iphoneos'
    xcWorkspacePath: 'something.xcworkspace'
    scheme: 'Something'
    packageApp: false
    args: '-UseModernBuildSystem=0'
```


**Proposed yaml**

```
- task: Xcode@5
  inputs:
    actions: 'build'
    configuration: 'Release'
    sdk: 'iphoneos'
    xcWorkspacePath: 'something.xcworkspace'
    scheme: 'Something'
    packageApp: false
    useModernBuildSystem: false
```
